componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Snap-on Incorporated. 2010 Fourth Quarter and Full-Year Results Conference. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Leslie Kratcoski, Vice President, Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lisa, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today to review Snap-on's fourth quarter 2010 results, which are detailed in our press release issued earlier this morning. We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Execut
componenttext:
Thanks, Lisa, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today to review Snap-on's fourth quarter 2010 results, which are detailed in our press release issued earlier this morning. 
We have on the call today Nick Pinchuk, Snap-on's Chief Executive Officer; and Aldo Pagliari, Snap-on's Chief Financial Officer. Nick will kick off our call this morning with his perspective on our performance. Aldo will then provide a more detailed review of our financial results. After Nick provides some closing thoughts, we'll take your questions.
As usual, we have provided slides to supplement our discussion. You can find a copy of these slides on our website, next to the audio icon for this call. These slides will be archived on our website, along with the transcript of today’s call.
Any statements made during this call relative to management’s expectations, estimates or beliefs or otherwise state management’s or the company’s outlook, plans or projections, are forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially from those made in such statements. Additional information and the factors that could cause our results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are contained in our SEC filings.
With that said, I'd now like to turn the call over to Nick Pinchuk. Nick?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As we look at our fourth quarter, we're once again encouraged both by our financial performance and by our advancements in the areas we've identified as being of strategic importance. Overall, volumes in the quart
componenttext:
Thanks, Leslie. Good morning, everyone. As we look at our fourth quarter, we're once again encouraged both by our financial performance and by our advancements in the areas we've identified as being of strategic importance. 
Overall, volumes in the quarter were up 13.6%, and the gains were widely spread across customer bases, across operating units and across geographies. Operating earnings rose nearly 44%, and the overall margin of 13 1/2% increased 270 basis points from last year powered by expansion in the operating company, as well us by the ramp up in our Financial Services profitability. Excluding the Financial Services operations, the 12.6% operating margin was up well over the 11.5% registered in 2009. 
Importantly, I think, the results confirmed continuing progress and the building momentum. It was the fourth consecutive quarter of year-over-year sales increases, and these results represent the largest of those gains. Also the operating margins were the highest of the year's, defining a bright line of progress throughout 2010. I believe it's clear that Snap-on closed out 2010 in a much stronger position than when we entered the year. Of course, there was improvement in the overall global economic environment, and we've taken advantage. But we've also strengthened our tactical execution driven by our commitment to the Snap-on Value Creation Processes, Rapid Continuous Improvement, or RCIs as we call it, innovation, customer connection, quality and safety. They continued to drive improvement. And the good news is that there's much more to gain. There's much more to go. 
Beyond that, we've achieved much more progress in those focus areas that we believe will be strategically decisive for our future, enhancing our franchisee network, expanding the company's presence with repair shop owners and managers, rolling the Snap-on brand out of the garage, extending into other mission-critical areas or arenas and building our physical capabilities in emerging markets. We're making progress in each of those areas. 
Now let me for a moment touch on what we're seeing in the economy and the related sales activity. It's actually a somewhat refreshing and a more straightforward discussion than we had in 2009. Most trends are in fact positive. Those areas that already demonstrated signs of recovery continue to show progress. Take for example the Tools group, serving professional automotive technicians, that business returned to pre-downturn levels in the third quarter, and the recovery was confirmed again in the fourth quarter. 
As part of that trend, activity in big-ticket items remains strong. These are longer payback products like hand held diagnostic units and undercar equipment or more discretionary items like tool storaging. We watch those particular sales trends because we believe they are reasonably accurate barometer of our customers' financial health and of their confidence. 
The strength in those big-ticket products was across the board with diagnostics and tools storage units driving increased sales to the Tools group and undercar equipment, especially high-value aligners bolstering sales in the repair systems and information group, which serves vehicle repair shop owners and managers. I think we can say the trends here were consistently encouraging throughout 2010. Each quarter had year-over-year gains in all three big-ticket categories, and the fourth quarter rise outpaced our overall sales increase.
We also continued to register recovered activity in the Industrial business with professional users in critical industries all across the globe. And beyond that, emerging markets have just continued to be robust, and the fourth quarter was no exception. So the areas I just discussed were continuation of the positive trends we saw in the earlier periods. But we also saw some additional favorable signs in the spaces that have been slower to recover. 
For example, our business that are tied to automotive OEM dealerships. Although the North American dealership base continues to contract and it is an ongoing challenge, we did see some considerable increases relating to essential tool distributions in both North America and Europe. In the fourth quarter we registered some solid gains as those customers became more willing to commit. In Europe, an area of mixed economies overall, we did see our strongest year-over-year increase in the fourth quarter, solid double digits. 
I already mentioned the continuing strength in undercar equipment in the region, but we also saw strong comparisons in the northern and central countries of Europe like Sweden and Germany and favorability in the Eastern emerging economies where we've added additional presence in Belarus and recently ramped up our production in the Minsk facility. So there are real positives in Europe. 
But the south, especially Spain, hasn't changed. It's still weak, and that's a market which is significant for us. It is a significant market for Snap-on. So overall, we registered an encouraging quarter, and that was encouraging while still fighting the headwinds generated by our major markets in the south of Europe and by the consolidation of the OEM dealership space. 
Now I'll provide some highlights for each of the segments and mention some of the progress we made on our strategic areas of focus. Commercial and Industrial, or C&I, posted a volume increase from 2009 of 15.4%. The operating earnings were up over $18 million recovering smartly to 12.6% of sales from the 6.8% registered last year. We're gaining position in C&I, and we're also seeing the benefits from RCI and from restructuring actions. 
Speaking of RCI, one of the real highlights in the quarter was a recognition of our power tool plant in Murphy, North Carolina as one of North America's 10 best [Audio Gap] It's an annual competition conducted by IndustryWeek magazine with which Snap-on has some experience. Our Milwaukee hand tool plant was a finalist last year. Excellence in manufacturing is sought out and evaluated, and the judges liked what they saw in Snap-on Murphy. 
IndustryWeek, in their comments, highlighted the breadth and depth of the RCI culture at Murphy as a key driver in that plant's excellence. Endorsements like that only come from hard work and dedication. So I congratulate and I thank the associates at our Murphy's facility for this success.
The C&I segment is also where we see clear one way from growth and leveraging our powerful brand to further penetrate market outside of automotive repair. Snap-on progress in serving new customers in critical industries is quite evident in our Industrial business' fourth quarter performance. Sales were up there about 17% from last year, with particular strength in international markets and that capped of a gain of over 20% for the full year. That progress was driven by both an increasingly clear customer focus and also by innovative new products specifically aimed at solutions for those particular segments, products such as the large tools for mining, tethered tools for working at heights and aerospace and energy industries and products with advanced technology like the Automated Tool Control unit or ATC for the aviation industry. 
You might remember that I mentioned the launch of ATC last quarter, and the reception since has been enthusiastic. Beyond that, we also established important partnerships with technical schools focused on automotive, aviation and alternative energy. We're putting Snap-on in at the ground-floor of careers pretext in those critical industries. We're confident it will pay off and make them Snap-on customers for life. All of those products helped drive our improved and growing position in this strategic arena. 
Also in the C&I group is where we have our Asian and emerging markets businesses. We spent the past few years building physicals in those geographies. 
During 2010, we expanded plants and launched new products designed specifically for those markets, from automotive hand held diagnostics to professional brand of hand tools. We're building the physicals primarily to serve in the local markets, but they're powered by Snap-on technology and expertise that reflect our history and legacy of innovation and productivity, and that gives us an advantage in those fragmented but growing markets. 
We can particularly see that growth in China and India, as increases continued at a rapid pace in both those markets. And I believe when you think of emerging markets, it's worth noting that the repair cycle is just getting started in those economies, and there's much more opportunity for Snap-on in that arena. Overall on the quarter and throughout 2010, the advances in C&I were marked by solid volume gains and improved profitability all across the group, and we see those businesses clearly moving forward along an extended runway for growth. 
Moving onto the Tools group, where we served professional automotive technicians. As I said, it's back above prerecession levels. Big-ticket activity is strong. The overall year-over-year fourth quarter volume gain of 12.8% was led by the U.S.. The operating margin was 9.6%. And it offers a bit of a complicated comparison because of non-comparable items both in 2009 and 2010. Aldo will provide some more detailed analysis. 
I'll just highlight that we recorded restructuring in the fourth quarter in the Tools group of $4.6 million. Absent that charge, the Tools group margin of 11.3% is in line with the full-year result and includes our focused support to successfully maintain the strength of our franchising network. I do believe that the relatively modest decline in the Tools group volume during 2009 and then having to be among the first to recover is a testimony to the strength of our franchisees. We recognized that advantage as we went into the turbulence. We were committed to maintaining and supporting the network through the difficulties, and by all accounts, it worked. 
The key indicators of franchise health are quite positive. Turnovers have been reduced. Cash collections are strong and delinquencies are at low levels. The advantage that is that the Snap-on franchisee network remains robust. I already spoke about big-ticket strengths. Here again, early on, we said that these categories would lead us out of the downturn and they have. 
And as I meet with the franchisees, their outlook is upbeat. We have record attendance at our annual conference earlier in the year. Over 2,000 franchises made additional commitments to attend refine field training programs. And as I meet with them, they're quite excited about our new award-winning products. Some of those are high-tech innovations like the VERDICT hand held diagnostic unit, and some are just great designs that demonstrate connection with our customers like low-profile ratchets, all-in-one wire stripper, crimpers and cutters or the compact-clutch version of the cordless CT 561 impact wrench. These three items and many others all have one thing in common. They make work easier for technicians operating in an ever-changing and ever increasingly tight space, and they've helped create the Tools group recovery. 
Aldo will talk in some detail about the results of the Financial Services segment, but I'll only say that we believe our in-house financing capabilities are a unique advantage. It's a special Snap-on feature that makes our franchisee network stronger. Bringing Snap-on Credit home, after we entered a joint venture with CIT has been a smooth transition. No interruptions to our franchisees or to our end-customers. 
We are confident we could execute on integrating the credit company, and we did just that. And as evidence of that successful integration, the Financial Services operation is demonstrating the same strong profitability ramp up we always expected. Snap-on Credit has been a strategic strength. It's now becoming a significant profit contributor, and we believe it's only going to get better. 
Now for some discussion on Repair Systems and Information or the RS&I group. Fourth quarter organic sales were up 16.8%, and the operating margin was 19.7%, both representing substantial improvements from last year. I already mentioned the big movers. Undercar equipment continued its fourth quarter trends of double-digit year-over-year increases. We've gained position in that arena around the world. 
We've also increased facilitation and essential tools activity through equipment solutions or EQS. The vehicle manufacturers are gaining more confidence, as we go forward, investing in service, and we're playing our part. We continue to invest in RS&I because we see the opportunity to make strategic gains with repair shop owners and managers and to expand our presence within shops of varying types. 
For example, the RS&I group is expanding in medium and heavy-duty truck repair, growing with investments in that segment. And we're investing in truck repair information, essential diagnostic tools for diesel engines and diagnostics products aimed particularly at fleet. Truck is an area that's a natural fit for Snap-on, and we are on the upswing. During the fourth quarter, that progress was rewarded when Snap-on product was used by the American Trucking Association at the repair information source for their SuperTech competition. It's a great opportunity to further introduce our product to fleet customers, and it was a fine endorsement of Snap-on for the heavy truck segment. 
Also during the year, Mitchell 1, our business that provides shop and repair information, launched new shop management software with expanded and integrated parts capabilities. The new offerings will make work easier for the shops, and it's helping strengthen Mitchell 1's already substantial repair shop position. 
I'll just wrap up the RS&I discussion with a final word about innovation. Snap-on has received significant attention and recognition for new products in the last year. One is the Quadriga, a fully automated tire changer, recently was the recipient of an Innovation Award from Professional Tool and Equipment News. Snap-on's cutting-edge 3D imaging technology along with Pro 42 [ph] Software around aligners is leading to gain in that important Aligner segment, a crucial segment for the Equipment business. And we have new wheel balancer technology. Technology that laser max tire wear and helps predict tire replacement need. It's the first of its kind in the industry. And of course, as we've mentioned before, we have the fully functional VERDICT diagnostic hand held unit. It set a new standard with WiFi access, integration of Mitchell 1 repair information and a wireless touchscreen, all in the technician's hands that allows remote use by the technician from anywhere in the shop. These are productivity enhancing tools. They're also attractive, quite attractive to shop owners and managers and their helping Snap-on expand its position with that important customer base. And they were, in the fourth quarter, a big contributor to the fourth quarter and the full-year RS&I achievement. 
So I think I can say, our fourth quarter was a furthering of the positive trend we've seen now for several periods. Organic sales were up over 13%, operating income up over 40%, and this was against the headwinds generated by the continued weakness in southern Europe and by the OEM dealership consolidation. Overall, we're encouraged by the results and by what they say about the clear runway for growth we have going forward. Now I'll turn the call over to Aldo for the financial review, then I'll make a few closing comments. Aldo?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. Our consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. Net sales in the fourth quarter of $697 million increased to 12.7% year-over-year. Excluding currency translation, organic sales increased to $83 million or 13.6%. The primary d
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. Our consolidated operating results are summarized on Slide 6. 
Net sales in the fourth quarter of $697 million increased to 12.7% year-over-year. Excluding currency translation, organic sales increased to $83 million or 13.6%. The primary drivers behind the year-over-year sales increase include double-digit sales growth across many of our businesses including sales to franchisees in the United States, customers in critical industries and emerging markets, and increased facilitation program activities with automotive OEM dealerships, including higher sales of essential tools. Sales of undercar equipment to repair facilities were also up significantly, driven by imaging alignment product sales gains across all major geographies. While continuing to be impacted by challenging economic conditions throughout southern Europe, sales in our European-based Hand Tool business also experienced year-over-year increases, particularly in northern Europe. 
Consolidated gross profit of $319 million in the quarter increased $34.1 million from 2009 levels, driven by higher sales, favorable manufacturing utilization and savings from ongoing Rapid Continuous Improvement or RCI initiatives and restructuring actions. These gross profit increases were partially offset by $6.5 million of lower year-over-year LIFO-related inventory valuation benefits. The higher LIFO benefits in 2009 resulted from inventory reductions including the liquidation of slow moving and excess inventories, as we adjusted production in response to the weakened demand during the economic downturn. As a result, consolidated gross margin of 45.7% in the quarter decreased to 30 basis points from 46% last year. 
Operating increases expenses in the quarter of $231 million increased approximately $18 million from the prior year primarily due to higher volume-related and other expenses including $4.1 million of higher U.S. pension expense largely due to the amortization of investment losses incurred in 2008 related to our domestic pension plan assets. Operating expenses were also impacted by $3.8 million of higher year-over-year performance-based incentive compensation expense and $1.7 million of higher stock-based mark-to-market expense. These operating expense increases were partially offset by $4.9 million of lower bad debt expense, $2.5 million of benefits from ongoing RCI and restructuring initiatives and $1.6 million favorable currency effects. As a percentage of sales, operating expenses of 33.1% in the quarter improved 140 basis points from 34.5% last year. 
Restructuring cost in the fourth quarter of 2010 of $5.8 million, compared to $6.7 million last year. Restructuring cost in 2010 include initial cost to consolidate our North American tool storage operations. For the full year, restructuring charges or $14.2 million in 2010, compared to $22 million incurred last year. 
Financial Services operating earnings of $9.4 million in the quarter improved $13.2 million from the fourth quarter 2009 loss of $3.8 million. On a sequential basis, Financial Services operating earnings improved $4.4 million from third quarter 2010 levels. As evidenced by the continued quarter-over-quarter improvements in the sequential operating performance, we expected operating earnings from Financial Services will continue to improve as the on-book finance Portfolio grows. We'll cover Financial Services in more detail in a few minutes. 
Interest expense of $14 million in the fourth quarter decreased slightly from 2009 levels, reflecting lower average debt levels partially offset by higher average interest rates. In December, we issued $250 million of 4.25% seven-year senior notes. The proceeds from these notes are being used for general corporate purposes, which may include the funding of Snap-on Credit on balance sheet finance portfolio and the August 2011 repayment of $200 million of debt upon its maturity. 
Incremental interest expense in the fourth quarter related to these notes was about $600,000. Going forward, interest expense associated with these new notes will approximate $2.7 million per quarter or about $0.03. 
Our fourth quarter of 2010 effective income tax rate of 30.1% compares favorably to 31.4% in the fourth quarter of last year. As noted in our earnings release, the fourth quarter 2010 effective income tax rate benefited primarily from non-recurring tax items including the late December extension of certain federal tax incentives. Finally, net earnings of in the quarter of $57.9 million or $0.99 per diluted share, including $0.06 from the non-recurring tax items, increased $21.3 million or $0.36 per diluted share from fourth quarter 2009 levels. 
With that, let's now turn to our segment results. Starting with the C&I group on Slide 7. Fourth quarter sales of $282 million improved 14 1/2% from fourth quarter 2009 levels. Excluding currency translation, organic sales increased more than 15%. The year-over-year sales increase was again driven by higher sales across all operating units, particularly by our businesses serving customers in critical industries and emerging markets. 
Gross profit in the C&I segment of $108 million in the quarter increased 28.4% from 2009 levels. This $24 million gross profit increase is primarily due to higher sales, $4.8 million of lower restructuring costs and $3.1 million of savings from ongoing RCI and restructuring initiatives. The gross profit comparison also benefited from improving manufacturing utilization, primarily in Europe, as a result of increased production levels. 
Gross margin of 38.4% improved 420 basis points from 34.2% last year including 200 basis points from the lower restructuring costs. Operating expenses in the quarter of $72.6 million increased $5.3 million from 2009 levels, primarily due to higher volume-related and other expenses. As a percentage of sales, operating expenses improved by 160 basis points year-over-year. 
Operating earnings of $35.4 million for the C&I segment in the fourth quarter of 2010 increased $18.6 million or more than doubled from 2009 levels. As a percentage of sales, operating margin in the C&I segment of 12.6% in the quarter improved 580 basis points from 6.8% last year. 
Turning now to Slide 8. On a worldwide basis, fourth quarter organic sales in the Snap-on Tools group increased 12.8% year-over-year including a 15.2% increase in the United States and a 6.7% increase in our international franchise operations. Fourth quarter gross profit in the Snap-on Tools group was $107 million in both years. Gross profit contributions in 2010 from higher sales were more than offset by $6.5 million of lower year-over-year LIFO-related inventory benefits and $4.6 million of higher restructuring costs. As mentioned earlier, the higher level of LIFO benefits in 2009 resulted from inventory reductions including the liquidation of slow moving and excess inventories, as we adjusted production in response to the weakened demand. 
Gross margin in the Snap-on Tools group was 40% in the fourth quarter of 2010, as compared to 45.3% last year, including a 440 basis point reduction from the year-over-year LIFO impacts and the higher restructuring costs. Operating expenses of $81.4 million in the quarter increased $7.1 million from 2009 levels, primarily due to higher volume-related and other expenses. 
As a percentage of sales, operating expenses of 30.4% improved 90 basis points from 31.3% last year. Including the impacts of lower LIFO-related inventory valuation benefits and higher restructuring costs, fourth quarter operating earnings for Snap-on Tools was $25.8 million or 9.6% of sales, compared to $33.1 million or 14% of sales last year. After adjusting for LIFO and restructuring in both years, operating income as a percentage of sales was comparable in both years. 
Turning to the Repair Systems and Information or RS&I group, shown on Slide 9. Fourth quarter sales of $232 million increased $30 million or 14.9% year-over-year. Excluding currency translation, sales increased 16.8% led by greater sales of undercar equipment in both the Americas and Europe, higher sales of diagnostics and Mitchell 1 information products and increased activity with automotive OEM dealerships primarily due to increased essential tool and facilitation program sales. Gross profit of $103 million in the quarter increased $10.4 million or 11.2% from 2009 levels, primarily due to higher sales and contributions from favorable manufacturing utilization as a result of increased production levels. 
As a percentage of sales, gross margin of 44.6% in the quarter decreased 140 basis points from 46% last year. This is primarily due to a  shift in sales mix that included greater sales of lower margin essential tool and facilitation program sales to OEM dealerships. Operating expenses of $57.6 million in the quarter decreased slightly from 2009 levels as higher volume-related, product-development and other costs are more than offset by $3.6 million of lower bad debt expense and $2.2 million of savings from ongoing RCI and restructuring initiatives. 
Operating earnings of $45.7 million in the quarter for RS&I segment increased $10.7 million or 30.6% from 2009 levels. As a percentage of sales, operating margin in the quarter of 19.7% improved 240 basis points from 17.3% last year. 
Now turning to Slide 10. Financial Services operating earnings of $9.4 million in the fourth quarter compares favorably to both third quarter 2010 earnings of $5 million and to fourth quarter 2009 loss of $3.8 million. The $13.2 million year-over-year increase in operating earnings primarily reflects the higher revenue contributions from Snap-on Credit's growing on-book finance portfolio. Originations in the quarter increased 7.5% compared to the prior year. 
Moving to Slide 11. As of 2010 year-end, our balance sheet includes gross financing receivables of $592 million from our U.S. Snap-on Credit operation and $141 million from our international finance subsidiaries, for a total financing portfolio of $733 million. In the United States, $491 million or 83% of the Snap-on Credit portfolio relates to extended credit loans to technicians. 
Snap-on Credit also continues to manage the run-off portfolio contracts owned by CIT, which totaled $260 million at year-end, and which is down $57 million from third quarter 2010 levels and down $330 million from year-end 2009 levels. For the full year, the on-book financing portfolio at Snap-on Credit grew about $325 million. Regarding finance portfolio losses and delinquency trends, these continue to be in line with our expectations. 
Now turning to Slide 12. Consolidated operating cash flow of $64.3 million for the quarter and $140.4 million for the year includes the effect of a $48 million discretionary cash contribution to our U.S. pension plans. Operating cash flow for the full year was also impacted by $112 million of higher levels of trade and other receivables and inventories, as a result of increased sales and customer demand. Our year-end cash position of $572 million increased $212 million from third quarter 2010 levels primarily due to the proceeds from the December note issuance and cash flow from operations. 
These cash increases were partially offset by the funding of new loans originated by Snap-on Credit and capital expenditures. As a result, free cash flow from the operating company was $25.8 million for the fourth quarter and $91.1 million for the full year. As anticipated, free cash flow from financial services was negative in 2010 as a result of funding new loan originations. We expect that the impact of loan originations on free cash flow will lessen over time once the on-book portfolio stabilizes. 
Capital expenditures of $28 million in the quarter and $51 million for the full year included the continued expansion of our manufacturing capabilities and lower cost regions and emerging markets. Investments have focused on increased efficiency and cost reduction and improvements at our Kenosha, Wisconsin R&D facilities and headquarters. 
As seen on Slide 13, working capital metrics improved year-over-year. Day sales outstanding for trade receivables of 61 days at  2010 year-end improved from 63 days last year. On a trailing 12-month basis, inventory turns at 2010 year-end of 4.7x improved considerably from 4.1x last year. 
Net debt at the end of the quarter was $598.6 million. Our net debt to cap ratio of 30.1% compares to 22.2% last year and 29.2% at the end of third quarter, reflecting the $250 million December note issuance. Excluding the $107.8 million withheld for the previously disclosed dispute with CIT, our year-end net debt-to-cap ratio would have been 33.7%. 
In addition to our $572 million in cash and our cash flows from operations, we continue to maintain a $500 million revolving credit facility, a $100 million asset-backed securitization facility and $20 million of committed bank loans. In addition to these facilities, our current A2P2 short-term credit rating allows us to access the commercial paper markets should we choose to do so. As of 2010 year-end, no amount were outstanding under any of these facilities. This concludes my remarks on our fourth quarter performance. 
Before turning the call back to Nick to provide his final thoughts, I'd like to mention some considerations for our 2011 outlook as covered in our press release. In 2011, we expect to incur $11 million of higher year-over-year pension expense, largely due to the amortization of investment losses incurred in 2008 related to our U.S. pension plan assets. Capital expenditures at 2011 are anticipated to be in the range of $55 million to $65 million, and we anticipate a full-year effective income tax rate of approximately 33%. And as discussed earlier, interest expense in our fourth quarter debt issuance will approximate $2.7 million or $0.03 per diluted share per quarter. With that, I'll now turn it back over to Nick.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aldo. Look, we believe the message of our fourth quarter is three-fold. First, the Snap-on Value Creation Processes are continuing to drive improvement. We saw the results in our new products, in our profits and achievements like the Murphy factor
componenttext:
Thanks, Aldo. Look, we believe the message of our fourth quarter is three-fold. First, the Snap-on Value Creation Processes are continuing to drive improvement. We saw the results in our new products, in our profits and achievements like the Murphy factory being named in the top 10 and in our successful integration of the credit company. 
And we believe there is a long road of progress still to be traveled. 
Secondly, many of our businesses have recovered, returning to prerecession levels. At the same time, we do have selected areas particularly southern Europe and the OEM dealership segment that have some way to go. Finally, we see in the results that our runways for growth are clear. We review substantially in the quarter while still facing the headwinds of Spain and the rest of southern Europe and the OEM dealerships segment. Those increases were driven by decisive strategic gains, enhancing our franchise network, expanding with shop owners, extending to critical industries and building in emerging markets. And we can see further and expansive opportunities in each of those areas. 
Overall, I think you remember, we said, entering the recession, that we would navigate the difficulties and emerge stronger than before. We believe the fourth quarter results continuing the trend defined through 2010 are evidence that we did just that. But most importantly, those results indicate that Snap-on is positioned quite well to capitalize on the abundant opportunities for growth that stretch out before us. 
Now before I turn the call over to the operator, I want to finish by thanking our associates and our franchisees. I know many of you are listening. The fourth quarter and the full-year results were only possible because of your efforts on behalf of Snap-on and because of your commitment to our team. for all of that, for your continuing support of our company, you have my congratulations, and you have my thanks. Now I'll turn the call over to the operator for questions. Operator?

componenttext: Well, I think we've said emerging markets it's, I think, we've said 59% is the U.S., about 26% in Europe, emerging markets is between 5% and 10%, in that regard. The emerging markets we generally say is growing faster than GDP. We saw pretty good growth in India particularly in the fourth quarter and the third quarter of this year. We're starting to see our business in India pick up quite a bit. I don't know if we foresaw that so much when we entered the year.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So out of curiosity since you call that out, what is driving the India growth?
componenttext: So out of curiosity since you call that out, what is driving the India growth?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jim, I think it's the new equipment products. We started out taking equipment focused on the China market and launching a mid-tier. You might remember we talked a bit about that in the beginning. The early penetration of China was around, I don't want to
componenttext: Jim, I think it's the new equipment products. We started out taking equipment focused on the China market and launching a mid-tier. You might remember we talked a bit about that in the beginning. The early penetration of China was around, I don't want to say skimming, but around the top-of-the-line product and the best garages. And then we got some experience and then we came out with a mid-tier line, aligners and balancers and tire changers. And when we introduced that in India, it took off quite smartly.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's off a small base. I think actually, I think, a lot of people have observed -- some others have observed and I think you could have observed with us. And I think I said in my remarks, we are early in the cycle, this repair cycle. Industrial companies
componenttext: It's off a small base. I think actually, I think, a lot of people have observed -- some others have observed and I think you could have observed with us. And I think I said in my remarks, we are early in the cycle, this repair cycle. Industrial companies around the country, I think, are up around 20% or 25%. What you see from us is a situation where the repair cycle hasn't started yet. You know the story, 300 million cars in United States and 45% are over 10 years old. 70 million in China, and they are all new. So we haven't actually seen our business as a broad sense, as an industry really grab hold yet. And that applies not only to automotive repair, but also to aerospace and a number of different things. Repair cycle's just starting. We're building to get there, and I think we have quite a bit of opportunity. And you can see that just as you compare other industrial companies, how they're represented in China and other places in emerging markets.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on RS&I, what impact does mix have on the margins there? Just trying to understand what this new segment, what the margin profile should look like going forward.
componenttext: And on RS&I, what impact does mix have on the margins there? Just trying to understand what this new segment, what the margin profile should look like going forward.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you're seeing the margin profile now. What happen is, is that you get some headwinds when the OEM facilitation business starts building and that happened in this quarter. That'd been under-represented in prior quarters. And when the OEM manufactur
componenttext: I think you're seeing the margin profile now. What happen is, is that you get some headwinds when the OEM facilitation business starts building and that happened in this quarter. That'd been under-represented in prior quarters. And when the OEM manufacturers start having these central tool distributions, those are lower margins, more than 10 points lower at a gross margin level. And I think what you're seeing now is a good base to model going forward. I don't think you're going to see a big mix change because I think the facilitation business is now reasonably represented as a mixed piece.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on the Tools group, Aldo, the LIFO comps kind of worked their way out at this point. So 2011 is more apples-to-apples?
componenttext: And on the Tools group, Aldo, the LIFO comps kind of worked their way out at this point. So 2011 is more apples-to-apples?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jim, it's a good characterization. Certainly as inventory builds, there will be some impact of LIFO but you won't have that year-over-year noise that you had in the fourth quarter of this year. So, yes, you characterized it correctly.
componenttext: Jim, it's a good characterization. Certainly as inventory builds, there will be some impact of LIFO but you won't have that year-over-year noise that you had in the fourth quarter of this year. So, yes, you characterized it correctly.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Then final one for me, on the Credit business, first, expected contribution from a cash basis this year. And secondly, any update on the CIT disputes?
componenttext: Then final one for me, on the Credit business, first, expected contribution from a cash basis this year. And secondly, any update on the CIT disputes?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: First off, we expect that as the portfolio grows, yes, you will see sequential improvement as we have seen consistently over the last quarters since the termination of the joint venture back in July of '09. So we don't provide the exact guidance on what t
componenttext: First off, we expect that as the portfolio grows, yes, you will see sequential improvement as we have seen consistently over the last quarters since the termination of the joint venture back in July of '09. So we don't provide the exact guidance on what that buildup will be, but you will see we expect it to be incremental improvements in each quarter, as we go forward. With respect to CIT, really there is no further update of consequence that we have a meeting scheduled with an arbitrator in the second quarter of this year. We are hoping of the matter will be fully resolved by that point in time, but really nothing much else to say in that matter.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question today will come from David Leiker, Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question today will come from David Leiker, Robert W. Baird.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Aldo, as we look forward on the gross profit line, with the LIFO, are we through the point now that on a go-forward basis, we're not going to see LIFO benefits flow through the income statement any more?
componenttext: Aldo, as we look forward on the gross profit line, with the LIFO, are we through the point now that on a go-forward basis, we're not going to see LIFO benefits flow through the income statement any more?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't believe we will see LIFO benefits, David. I would expect that as the economy continues to recover and we continue to grow inventories, we'll take off appropriately so. And with that, if anything, you will have some LIFO expense creep into the fina
componenttext: I don't believe we will see LIFO benefits, David. I would expect that as the economy continues to recover and we continue to grow inventories, we'll take off appropriately so. And with that, if anything, you will have some LIFO expense creep into the financials but not benefits.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And how big do you think those expenses might end up running? Any thoughts?
componenttext: And how big do you think those expenses might end up running? Any thoughts?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I do not think they'll be significant.
componenttext: I do not think they'll be significant.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then as we look at the organic performance across the businesses, Tools business and Diagnostics both have seen an acceleration and that's relative to what we saw in the prior quarters. Is that something that we're seeing some real the strong underlyi
componenttext: And then as we look at the organic performance across the businesses, Tools business and Diagnostics both have seen an acceleration and that's relative to what we saw in the prior quarters. Is that something that we're seeing some real the strong underlying growth there accelerate or is there something else going on?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, actually the Tools business looks fairly strong. It's hard to say. I think we are seeing some real positives there. I think I said in the last call, everybody says they're gaining share. I think we feel quite confident that we're improving
componenttext: Well, I think, actually the Tools business looks fairly strong. It's hard to say. I think we are seeing some real positives there. I think I said in the last call, everybody says they're gaining share. I think we feel quite confident that we're improving our position with technicians in the Tools group. I think you're seeing technicians themselves become a little bit more confident of their future. It's not necessarily pent-up demand, it's just that they're going to back to business as usual in terms of buying. We just had a kick off, David, and the kick-off events were, I think, our best ever. And these are events which lead off the year. We hold them in January and then distribute them around the country in places like Chicago and Deadwood, South Dakota and Phoenix and so on. And the attendance at those was a record, and the enthusiasm for the programs that are coming forward was very positive. So I'd have to say that the anecdotal reports from the individual dealers -- I attended a couple of them myself -- the anecdotal reports from the dealers seem to match up with the numbers to say that we're gaining position. And then it looks like that, that group is getting its momentum moving forward positively. We have recovered. It recovered from -- I think we're back to 2008 levels. So you can say we're at pre levels, so the fourth quarter I think is a pretty good quarter for them.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you think that if you look at the business here in the U.S. in particular, in the Tools side that you're back to normal customer behavior?
componenttext: Do you think that if you look at the business here in the U.S. in particular, in the Tools side that you're back to normal customer behavior?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say that. I'd say we're seeing -- in the United States, the business grew 16%, 15%, 16% so big number. We feel pretty positive about that, and I wouldn't call it pent-up demand. I just think customers are -- they've been fortified by the continui
componenttext: Yes, I'd say that. I'd say we're seeing -- in the United States, the business grew 16%, 15%, 16% so big number. We feel pretty positive about that, and I wouldn't call it pent-up demand. I just think customers are -- they've been fortified by the continuing demand in the shops, even through recession. Now they're getting more that confident, and they're going to back to business as usual. And by the way, we are stronger than when we entered. Our franchisees are stronger. The cash is better. The terminations is better, and our products are better.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then same kind of question on the Repair side, is that back to normal level of demands or not yet?
componenttext: And then same kind of question on the Repair side, is that back to normal level of demands or not yet?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's back to normal levels of demand. Of course, the cost gets tougher in 2011 as you know, but I feel positive about that business.
componenttext: I think it's back to normal levels of demand. Of course, the cost gets tougher in 2011 as you know, but I feel positive about that business.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, I was a little late getting on but Europe, the southern part of the region, particularly the C&I business has been a bit of a lag. Has that gotten back? Is that starting to perform like the other now?
componenttext: And then lastly, I was a little late getting on but Europe, the southern part of the region, particularly the C&I business has been a bit of a lag. Has that gotten back? Is that starting to perform like the other now?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bouncing along the bottom, I'd say. That's how I describe it. Some quarters -- if you go back and you look at the last couple of quarters, last couple three quarters, there's a body of work. Here to say, this business is bouncing along the bottom. I don't
componenttext: Bouncing along the bottom, I'd say. That's how I describe it. Some quarters -- if you go back and you look at the last couple of quarters, last couple three quarters, there's a body of work. Here to say, this business is bouncing along the bottom. I don't think we're seeing recovery yet there. So if you think about us going forward, you can think of us this way, we have a number of businesses that are fully recovered, and then we've got places that have still kind of caught in the kind of recession level, which is the OEM dealership business for reasons of consolidation and the Southern European business. I think that's how you can look at us going forward.

componenttext: I don't think so. I think our peak seasonality quarter is the third quarter. It's the third quarter, because we have European businesses, and so you see vacations flow through the numbers. But generally, we have little seasonality in the other three quarters. Now there can be a little turbulence in expense because when you start out the year you're spending on things, like I said the kick-off meetings and so on. The expense line can move somewhat based on those things. But generally, I'd say in terms of the top line, in terms of performance, pretty much no seasonality.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's right. I would say that we think moving forward -- I'm not going to say that we're not going to add any working capital as our sales move upwards, that's not the situation. But I think the free cash flow from what we call OpCo, the operating company, outside the Financial Services we'll be pretty robust.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's true. The one exception to that might be, if you say, as you expand in emerging markets that tends to be a structural build. So that's a little different, but generally, the rest of the business. I would say that in a broad sense, you're correct.

componenttext: $14.2 million this year and last year we spent just over $20 million, $22 million or something like that. I think we consider ourselves controlled restructures. We spend about in that area every year. So I think you're going to see about that level going forward.

componenttext: I'm not saying we're going to spend that amount this year or less. But that's kind of money -- if you go back and you look at what we've done in the past, it's a kind of money we spent. That's generally what we can handle in a year. We feel pretty positive about doing it. We feel we can execute it. So those are the kinds of numbers we generally turn out. We see opportunities.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: It's really a bit just more program specific. The restructuring definition is an accounting terminology, and if it's a specific and unique program as compared at the prior year, it's categorized by that. So I think what Nick is saying is we still see opportunities to improve ourselves. We're going to continue to look for those opportunities, and we will invest accordingly if we see a return on those projects.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Any ideas of that moving up in fiscal '11?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have some open routes that we could fill and they are structural. And as we get more efficient, the structural nature of our open routes can get filled. I think we found that we want to be very selective in who we put in the trucks, and it served us ve
componenttext: We have some open routes that we could fill and they are structural. And as we get more efficient, the structural nature of our open routes can get filled. I think we found that we want to be very selective in who we put in the trucks, and it served us very well going forward. And so that's really the idea that's dominated the last four, five quarters. That doesn't mean we won't increase in the future.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you have intend to purge as much because as much because of such a higher standard? .
componenttext: So you have intend to purge as much because as much because of such a higher standard? .

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. If you actually got here and you look at all the real detail, our infant mortality is one way down, which has made all the difference for us in terms of termination. So that's been a very big positive as you might imagine. I would say that you woul
componenttext: Right. If you actually got here and you look at all the real detail, our infant mortality is one way down, which has made all the difference for us in terms of termination. So that's been a very big positive as you might imagine. I would say that you would be entitled to believe that over the last, say, two or three years, we've learned a lot how to manage the franchise systems with lower cost associated with turbulence in the franchisees. We've made a lot of attention to their profitability as well. So we boosted their profits on an average basis and then paid attention who's going in there, and that all works pretty well. Actually, it's one of the things I just want to say a little bit more. It's one of the great advantages of Snap-on because when you have a so many franchisees, you may have a big portion of the 3,500 people in the United States who are capable of running these franchisees. It's kind of a barrier to entry and a tactical advantage that's hard to duplicate and hard to deal with for some of our competitors.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And what was the growth in Tools for international? Was it 6.7%, Aldo?
componenttext: And what was the growth in Tools for international? Was it 6.7%, Aldo?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: 6.7% was the growth outside United States in the quarter.
componenttext: 6.7% was the growth outside United States in the quarter.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you guys mentioned before it's pretty difficult to implement a van strategy into India or China. Is that right?
componenttext: I think you guys mentioned before it's pretty difficult to implement a van strategy into India or China. Is that right?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, generally it is difficult because the van strategy flourishes best when the technicians own their own tools. India and China, the technicians do not own the tools, the shops own them. So we use direct and distributors to manage our distribut
componenttext: No. Actually, generally it is difficult because the van strategy flourishes best when the technicians own their own tools. India and China, the technicians do not own the tools, the shops own them. So we use direct and distributors to manage our distribution in that place. Just an aside for the international businesses, remember that if you look back to last year when we're in the recession, the international Tools business did not go down. The international van channels did not sink as much as other U.S. businesses. So the comparisons were much tougher for those, U.K. and Australia businesses.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In your mission-critical areas, was there any particular areas that was more growth outstanding in the quarter or was it just across the board?
componenttext: In your mission-critical areas, was there any particular areas that was more growth outstanding in the quarter or was it just across the board?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, we grew at every one of those areas in the quarter, and we are quite pleased with that. But I would say that if you ask me that question, the broad category of natural resources seem to be the strongest. Things like mining and oil and gas -- we
componenttext: Actually, we grew at every one of those areas in the quarter, and we are quite pleased with that. But I would say that if you ask me that question, the broad category of natural resources seem to be the strongest. Things like mining and oil and gas -- we put power generation and natural resources. So we felt that to be a pleasing trend.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: And I know you mentioned that Europe represented what, 26% of revenue. Would you be able to say how much is like southern Europe in that 26%?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I can say that our Spanish -- I'll say this, I know that Spanish number. Our Spanish number is between 20% and 25% of our European business. We acquired a business in Spain several years ago, one of our major acquisitions, so we have a fairly large share
componenttext: I can say that our Spanish -- I'll say this, I know that Spanish number. Our Spanish number is between 20% and 25% of our European business. We acquired a business in Spain several years ago, one of our major acquisitions, so we have a fairly large share of the Spanish market.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Lastly, is there any -- are you guys looking at any small tuck-in acquisitions instead? That does that make any sense...
componenttext: Lastly, is there any -- are you guys looking at any small tuck-in acquisitions instead? That does that make any sense...

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our view on acquisitions is this, is that the Snap-on umbrella -- we used to think of ourselves as somebody who sold hand tools through vans to auto mechanics. But with a step back at it, the real Snap-on proposition is making work easier for profess
componenttext: Yes. Our view on acquisitions is this, is that the Snap-on umbrella -- we used to think of ourselves as somebody who sold hand tools through vans to auto mechanics. But with a step back at it, the real Snap-on proposition is making work easier for professionals who operate in critical industries. That's a fairly wide but yet coherent space where the whole Snap-on proposition works powerfully, and so we're looking at acquisitions in those areas. We're receptive to acquisitions that, in emerging markets, an acquisition that would put us in a better position to serve repair shop owners and managers -- we've made one several years ago called ProQuest -- or anybody, anything that would further and give us greater weight in critical industries and alternative energy in places like natural resources or aerospace and so on. So we're alert to those ,and we're reviewing them.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: What about in -- I know your gaining ground in the heavy medium truck, is that anywhere where acquisition would help or is that more of organic?
componenttext: What about in -- I know your gaining ground in the heavy medium truck, is that anywhere where acquisition would help or is that more of organic?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't necessarily see us looking at that for an acquisition. I think we have quite a bit of capability right inside Snap-on to fully mine that position. People always ask me what are we going to do with our cash. Well, I think we have quite a bit of cap
componenttext: I don't necessarily see us looking at that for an acquisition. I think we have quite a bit of capability right inside Snap-on to fully mine that position. People always ask me what are we going to do with our cash. Well, I think we have quite a bit of capability, quite a bit of runway in rolling the Snap-on brand out of the garage and building an emerging market on expanding with repair shop owners and managers. Remember that's a different customer base than technicians. And so, we're investing in organic growth there. But we are looking for acquisition. I'm not sure heavy truck is a clear opportunity, but that doesn't mean I would disqualify it if a great property came or is available.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our final question today is a follow-up from Jim Lucas.
componenttext: Our final question today is a follow-up from Jim Lucas.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And any thoughts or color you could share on the ramp up material inflation we're seeing in particular, a lot of press these days is about the rising steel prices. If you could just kind of give us an update of where you stand in terms of price being able
componenttext: And any thoughts or color you could share on the ramp up material inflation we're seeing in particular, a lot of press these days is about the rising steel prices. If you could just kind of give us an update of where you stand in terms of price being able to offset this rising inflation?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We had some pricing in the quarter. We're seeing some mild inflation. Remember, we don't buy any particular one quantity. I think we've said in the past that to the extent the inflation is quite visible, that is steel prices go up, clearly, or oil prices
componenttext: We had some pricing in the quarter. We're seeing some mild inflation. Remember, we don't buy any particular one quantity. I think we've said in the past that to the extent the inflation is quite visible, that is steel prices go up, clearly, or oil prices spiked, dramatically and stay up .These prices are up  and things like that, we can price for that. We think we can find offset. We can find offsets for those for that pressure. And if you go back -- the last time we saw spikes in 2008. I think gasoline was like $4 a gallon and so on in 2008. Oil went from 80 to 140. That was one of our best years. So I don't think we're trembling over commodity inflation. I'm not to say it isn't a challenge but in history we've been able to find ways to offset it.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just from clarification standpoint, when do you normally put your -- if I remember correctly, it's usually an annual price increase you put through and then to your response of being able to pass through when inflation is visible. Is there a normal lag fr
componenttext: Just from clarification standpoint, when do you normally put your -- if I remember correctly, it's usually an annual price increase you put through and then to your response of being able to pass through when inflation is visible. Is there a normal lag from when you realize that price?

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, across the range of businesses, there's no particular period I can say that we put in pricing. I mean the Tools group is different than SNA Europe, that's different in Asia and so on. You can say, I think that there's a kind of maybe qu
componenttext: Yes. First of all, across the range of businesses, there's no particular period I can say that we put in pricing. I mean the Tools group is different than SNA Europe, that's different in Asia and so on. You can say, I think that there's a kind of maybe quarter lag in this kind of thing. We'll see a two- to three-month lag and when we put in pricing and see it come out of the marketplace.

headline: Snap-on Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: .And at this time, there are no further questions. I'll turn the conference back over to management for any additional or closing remarks.
